title: Automatic Speech Recognition for Non-Native English: Accuracy and Disfluency Handling
author: Michael McGuire (Doshisha University, Kyoto, Japan)
relevance_why: The study evaluates the performance of various automated speech recognition systems, which aligns with the research on improving audio processing technologies related to non-native speech recognition and applications in language learning.
background: Assessing the effectiveness of automated speech recognition systems in accurately transcribing non-native English speech while also analyzing their ability to manage speech disfluencies.
contribution: This paper introduces a comparison of five advanced automatic speech recognition systems to solve the challenge of accurately recognizing non-native accented English, achieving insights on their accuracy and handling of disfluencies.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous ASR systems showed higher error rates for accented speech, often lacking sufficient training data for non-native pronunciations and disfluency management.
technical_comparison.novelty: By evaluating systems on a diverse set of non-native speakers and analyzing their disfluency handling, this work offers detailed comparisons and meaningful insights on current ASR performance.

key_innovation: Focuses on both the recognition accuracy for various accent backgrounds and the handling of different types of disfluencies in non-native speech.
real_world_impact: The insights from this study can significantly enhance the design and implementation of practical language learning tools that utilize ASR technology for better learner outcomes.
limitations: The study does not examine ASR systems in real-world conversational contexts, focusing primarily on controlled reading and narrative tasks.

new_terms.Match Error Rate (MER): **Match Error Rate (MER)** is a metric used to assess ASR accuracy by measuring the probability of any word in a transcription being incorrect relative to the total words spoken.
